ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Overview of the History of Hong Kong from around 1800 to present day. Effect of China-wide historical policies especially on Souther China.

the comprehensive survey of the history of Hong Kong and its relation to China through a multidisciplinary approach; the necessary context to engage in formal conversations about current events on this topic

The importance of historical specificity,
Historical writing

This course not only taught me about the history between China and Hong Kong but also about how to analyze that history and convey it in words. Professor Ho structured the class in a way that led students through the process of writing a history paper by breaking the process down into multiple parts. It connected really well with the content which touched on different aspects of Hong Kong and Chinese history such as education, women, and economy.
This course taught me how to interact differently with different types of sources, such as primary sources, ethnographies, journal articles, etc.
Better understanding into the history of Hong Kong and different perspectives that shaped Hong Kong peoples views of themselves and the world around them.

I gained deeper insights to knowledge of Hong Kong's history and relations with mainland China and the UK. It was a pro for the professor to use diverse sources of history and news pieces in order to construct a comprehensive picture of Hong Kong. It was also a great comparison to see Shenzhen in the meantime.
Answered in the section of HIST 303J.
I gained great insight into the history and and politics of Hong Kong.
Academic writing skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
This course had great readings, especially the books (Carrol, Chen Village and Chan). The way the writing assignments were organised (three smaller essays, each a part of a longer history essay) were extremely helpful for the final paper. The course is also varied in its academic subjects: Primarily history in the first half, social sciences in the second. Workload was manageable and fair.

I do not have many complaints about the course. The only aspect of which I was not quite sure were the weekly reading responses. While I understand that they were meant to make sure everyone did the readings, apart from a few mentions of them in class, they often felt quite disconnected from the section discussion. Reading them, it felt like we were all talking past each other. Maybe a different reading response format that would make it feel mroe like a discussion woudl ehlp the responses feel more integrated. Maybe having part of the class write a response and then having the rest respond to those would work. Or maybe a format similar to "The Conversation" in the NYT where students meet in groups of 2-4 each week and write a log of their conversation on the readings.

strength: Prof. Ho's curation of reading assignments is one of the finest and most interesting I have had, and I am a History senior. I truly appreciated their breadth and depth; Prof. Ho's passion and expertise on the topic made this class so insightful and fruitful. The level of support and feedback she gave to each of us was also unparalleled -- with the written assignments, she really helped me re-examine my own writing and pushed it to the next level 

weakness: none. It's a superb seminar
discussion can be more guided. Maybe it's better to give feed back digitally

Professor Ho's seminar was insightful and probably one of the most useful courses I have taken at Yale. The way she structured the writing assignments were helpful and made the writing process easier to understand and improve. I definitely learned a lot about specific events in Hong Kong and Chinese history, especially focusing on Shenzhen. However, I think if we had more time I would have loved to be able to get a deeper understanding of both individual histories to see how they connect. Of course, Professor Ho does assign a reading that summarizes Hong Kong history in 200 pages or so, but as someone who came into the class with less background, it was a little challenging to keep up.

Strengths: highly engaging, organized, readings are relevant and interesting, the professor gives great feedback, class discussions are exciting, the professor created a supportive environment where people felt comfortable sharing their opinion in class. Weaknesses: lots of assisgned reading.
Good primary materials, but can be a bit much to go through.

I believe the strengths would be the professor's choices of this course's structure, the choice of diverse historical journals/data/books/news-pieces that would reflect the whole picture of what happened and would potentially happen to the land of Hong Kong. I enjoyed this course very much and I believe it was my favorite in the past semester. The only thing I believe could have been bettered was that the discussion leaders should have planned orders of discussion topics, and followed them categories by categories, in order to keep the whole course constituent and engaging at all times.
Answered in the section of HIST 303J.
Very engaging seminar with lots of great discussions.
Can't think of any.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. I think it is more accessible to many students than other East Asian History courses because it requires no knowledge of previous history. If you are willing to do the readings, it is a great course. If you are lucky, the course will also include grad students, which helps keep the level of discussion quite high. If you are interested in China or Hong Kong, I would recommedn taking thsi course.
ABSOLUTELY! You will learn so much from Prof. Ho.

Yes, I found studying Hong Kong and constantly analyzing its relationship with China throughout the course of history very interesting. This was not an area of history I was particularly familiar with, however, the course is balanced just enough that you are challenged without feeling left behind. Would certainly recommend.
Yes.
Yes, absolutely take this course if you have the chance! Professor Ho is a wonderful professor and the class is a great class to add to your history courseload.

ABSOLUTELY! one of my favorite classes I've taken at Yale so far. I came into the class not knowing anything about Hong Kong and left being able to engage in high-level conversations about Hong Kong in history and in a modern-day context. This class went chronologically, which really helped me learning.
Yes. This is a great overview of Hong Kongs history for those who are interested in studying it.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It is a great course to understand the pre-modern to the modern history of Hong Kong and relations to mainland China, as well as to the West. Hong Kong is a window for Asia to the world, and it's also a window for Westerners to understand China as well (also a great opportunity for mainland Chinese students to learn about their Hong Kong counterparts).
Answered in the section of HIST 303J.
Id highly recommend the course. The content is super interesting and the discussions are very engaging and insightful.
Yes. Professor Ho is very helpful and caring. Academically rigorous but approachable.
